Package io.github.ai4ci.abm.inhost

Interface InHostStochasticState

All Superinterfaces:
InHostModelState<StochasticModel>, Serializable
@Immutable public interface InHostStochasticState extends InHostModelState<StochasticModel>
A stochastic difference equation model of in-host viral dynamics and immune response.

This model simulates the discrete-time evolution of key compartments:

  • Virions: free viral particles,
  • Target cells: susceptible, exposed (latently infected), infected, and removed,
  • Immune cells: dormant, priming, and active (effector).

Transitions between compartments are modeled as stochastic events using binomial and Poisson sampling, capturing demographic and interaction noise. The model supports external inputs such as:

  • New virion exposure (infection),
  • Immunization (immune priming).

The dynamics are governed by per-time-step rates, converted to probabilities via \( p = 1 - e^{-r} \). This ensures consistency with continuous-time interpretations while enabling efficient discrete simulation.

See Also:
  • Poisson Binomial Distribution
  • Set Coverage Problem

  • Method Details

    • getBaselineViralInfectionRate

      @Redacted double getBaselineViralInfectionRate()
      Gets the baseline viral infection rate.

      This rate controls how efficiently viral particles infect susceptible target cells. Higher rates lead to more rapid target cell depletion and faster infection progression.

      Returns:
      the baseline viral infection rate

    • getBaselineViralReplicationRate

      @Redacted double getBaselineViralReplicationRate()
      Gets the baseline viral replication rate.

      This rate controls how quickly infected cells produce new viral particles. Higher rates lead to faster viral load increase and more rapid infection progression.

      Returns:
      the baseline viral replication rate

    • getImmune

      @Default default Integer getImmune()
      Gets the total number of immune cells in the system.

      Calculated as the product of target cells and immune-target ratio. Represents the total immune capacity, distributed across dormant, priming, and active states.

      Returns:
      the total immune cell count

    • getImmuneActivationRate

      double getImmuneActivationRate()
      Gets the activation rate for immune cell priming in response to infection.

      This rate controls how quickly dormant immune cells transition to priming state when exposed to infected or exposed target cells. Higher rates lead to faster immune response initiation.

      Returns:
      the immune activation rate

    • getImmuneActive

      int getImmuneActive()
      Gets the count of active effector immune cells.

      Active immune cells are responsible for viral neutralization and infected cell clearance. Their activity level modulates infection and clearance rates throughout the simulation.

      Returns:
      the count of active immune cells

    • getImmuneActivity

      @Derived default double getImmuneActivity()
      Computes immune activity as the fraction of immune cells that are active (effector) state.

      Defined as: \[ I_{\text{activity}} = \frac{I_{\text{active}}}{I_{\text{total}}} \] where \( I_{\text{total}} = \text{floor}(T_{\text{total}} \cdot r_I) \), and \( r_I \) is the immune-to-target ratio. This normalized activity modulates viral clearance and infection rates.

      Specified by:
      getImmuneActivity in interface InHostModelState<StochasticModel>
      Returns:
      immune activity as a fraction of maximum capacity

    • getImmuneDormant

      @Derived default int getImmuneDormant()
      Computes the number of immune cells in the dormant (naive or memory) state.

      Defined as: \[ I_{\text{dormant}} = I_{\text{total}} - I_{\text{priming}} - I_{\text{active}} \] These cells can be activated by infection or immunization.

      Returns:
      count of dormant immune cells

    • getImmunePriming

      int getImmunePriming()
      Gets the count of immune cells in priming state.

      Priming cells have recognized antigen but are not yet fully active effectors. They represent the intermediate stage in immune activation between dormant and active states.

      Returns:
      the count of priming immune cells

    • getImmuneTargetRatio

      double getImmuneTargetRatio()
      Gets the ratio of immune cells to target cells in the system.

      This ratio determines the baseline immune capacity relative to the target cell population. Higher ratios indicate stronger innate immune responses.

      Returns:
      the immune-to-target cell ratio

    • getImmuneWaningRate

      double getImmuneWaningRate()
      Gets the waning rate for active immune cells transitioning to senescence.

      This rate determines how quickly active effector immune cells lose their effectiveness and transition to a senescent state. Lower rates result in longer-lasting immune protection.

      Returns:
      the immune waning rate

    • getInfectionCarrierProbability

      double getInfectionCarrierProbability()
      Gets the probability that an exposed cell becomes a chronic infection carrier.

      This probability determines whether exposed cells avoid immune clearance and remain in a latent reservoir, potentially leading to persistent or chronic infections.

      Returns:
      the chronic infection carrier probability

    • getNormalisedSeverity

      @Derived default double getNormalisedSeverity()
      Computes a proxy for disease severity based on the proportion of non-susceptible target cells.

      Severity is defined as: \[ S(t) = \frac{T_{\text{total}} - T_{\text{susceptible}}(t) - T_{\text{exposed}}(t)}{T_{\text{total}}} \] which reflects the fraction of targets that have been infected and progressed beyond latency. This assumes severity correlates with cumulative tissue damage.

      Specified by:
      getNormalisedSeverity in interface InHostModelState<StochasticModel>
      Returns:
      the proportion of targets that are infected or removed

    • getNormalisedViralLoad

      @Derived default double getNormalisedViralLoad()
      Description copied from interface: InHostModelState
      Returns the normalized viral load, typically scaled relative to a reference infectiousness threshold.

      This value is used in transmission models to compute the probability of infectious contact: \[ p_{\text{transmit}} \propto f(V_{\text{norm}}) \] where \( V_{\text{norm}} = V / V_{\text{cutoff}} \). The exact functional form depends on the model.

      Specified by:
      getNormalisedViralLoad in interface InHostModelState<StochasticModel>
      Returns:
      normalized viral load (unitless, â‰¥ 0)

    • getTargetExposed

      int getTargetExposed()
      Gets the count of exposed (latently infected) target cells.

      These cells have been infected but are not yet actively producing virions. They may progress to infected state, be cleared by immune response, or remain as chronic carriers.

      Returns:
      the count of exposed target cells

    • getTargetInfected

      int getTargetInfected()
      Gets the count of infected target cells actively producing virions.

      These cells are the primary source of new viral particles through replication. They contribute to disease severity and can be cleared by immune response or cellular removal processes.

      Returns:
      the count of infected target cells

    • getTargetRecoveryRate

      double getTargetRecoveryRate()
      Gets the recovery rate for removed target cells returning to susceptible state.

      This rate controls the regeneration of target cells from the removed pool, representing tissue repair and cell turnover processes. Higher rates lead to faster recovery of susceptible cell populations.

      Returns:
      the target cell recovery rate

    • getTargetRemoved

      @Derived default int getTargetRemoved()
      Computes the number of target cells that are no longer susceptible due to recovery, death, or removal.

      This is derived from conservation of total targets: \[ T_{\text{removed}} = T_{\text{total}} - T_{\text{susceptible}} - T_{\text{exposed}} - T_{\text{infected}} \]

      Returns:
      the count of removed (non-susceptible, non-infected) target cells

    • getTargets

      int getTargets()
      Gets the total number of target cells available for viral infection.

      This represents the fixed pool size of susceptible cells that can be infected. The total target count remains constant throughout the simulation, with individual cells transitioning between susceptible, exposed, infected, and removed states.

      Returns:
      the total number of target cells

    • getTargetSusceptible

      int getTargetSusceptible()
      Gets the count of susceptible target cells available for infection.

      These are healthy cells that can be infected by viral particles. The susceptible pool decreases as cells become exposed and increases as removed cells recover.

      Returns:
      the count of susceptible target cells

    • getTime

      int getTime()
      Gets the current simulation time step.

      Represents the discrete time index in the simulation. Each time step typically corresponds to one day in the infection progression timeline.

      Specified by:
      getTime in interface InHostModelState<StochasticModel>
      Returns:
      the current time step

    • getVirions

      int getVirions()
      Gets the current count of free viral particles (virions) in circulation.

      This includes both infectious and non-infectious viral particles. Virions can infect target cells, be neutralized by immune cells, or be produced by infected cells.

      Returns:
      the current virion count

    • getVirionsDiseaseCutoff

      @Redacted int getVirionsDiseaseCutoff()
      Gets the disease cutoff value for virion normalization.

      This parameter defines the reference virion count used to normalize viral load measurements. It represents a clinically relevant threshold for disease severity assessment.

      Returns:
      the virion disease cutoff value

    • getVirionsProduced

      int getVirionsProduced()
      Gets the count of newly produced virions in the current time step.

      This represents the viral replication output from infected target cells. Used to distinguish between newly produced virions and those from previous time steps or external exposure.

      Returns:
      the count of newly produced virions

    • update

      default InHostStochasticState update(Sampler rng, double virionDose, double immunisationDose)
      Advances the in-host state by one time step using stochastic difference equations.

      The update models the following biological processes:

      • Viral replication: Poisson-distributed production from infected cells,
      • Neutralization: Binomial clearance by active immunity,
      • Infection: Stochastic infection of susceptible targets,
      • Immune activation: Priming and activation cascades,
      • Cell turnover: Recovery of target cells and waning of immunity.

      Infection of Target Cells

      The number of target cells that interact with virions is modeled using the coverage problem from combinatorics. When \( n \) virions sample from \( S \) susceptible targets with replacement, the expected number of unique targets hit is: \[ \mathbb{E}[\text{interacted}] = S \left(1 - e^{-n/S}\right) \] This approximates the solution to the classic problem of set coverage after independent random sampling (see reference).

      From these interacting targets, a binomial sample determines how many become exposed, with probability \( p_{\text{infection}} = 1 - e^{-r_{\text{infect}} \cdot S/T} \).

      Immune Dynamics

      Immune activation depends on the burden of exposed and infected cells: \[ p_{\text{priming}} = 1 - e^{-r_{\text{prime}} \cdot (T_e + T_i)/T} \] Active immunity wanes at rate \( r_{\text{waning}} \), modeled as a binomial decay process.

      Chronic Infection

      A fixed probability \( p_{\text{chronic}} \) determines whether an exposed cell avoids immune clearance and remains in a latent reservoir.
      Specified by:
      update in interface InHostModelState<StochasticModel>
      Parameters:
      rng - the random sampler for stochastic transitions
      virionDose - the external virion exposure, scaled by disease cutoff
      immunisationDose - the immunization strength, interpreted as fraction of dormant immunity to prime
      Returns:
      a new state advanced by one time unit
